message_text:
<paper>
Paper Title: Political Polarization on Twitter
Paper Abstract: In this study we investigate how social media shape the networked public sphere and facilitate communication between communities with different political orientations. We examine two networks of political communication on Twitter, comprised of more than 250,000 tweets from the six weeks leading up to the 2010 U.S. congressional midterm elections. Using a combination of network clustering algorithms and manually-annotated data we demonstrate that the network of political retweets exhibits a highly segregated partisan structure, with extremely limited connectivity between left- and right-leaning users. Surprisingly this is not the case for the user-to-user mention network, which is dominated by a single politically heterogeneous cluster of users in which ideologically-opposed individuals interact at a much higher rate compared to the network of retweets. To explain the distinct topologies of the retweet and mention networks we conjecture that politically motivated individuals provoke interaction by injecting partisan content into information streams whose primary audience consists of ideologically-opposed users. We conclude with statistical evidence in support of this hypothesis.
</paper>

<paper_classification>
"contribution" = proposes something new (method, technique, dataset, framework, benchmark, etc.)
"survey" = literature review, overview, meta-analysis, position papers (only references existing work)
</paper_classification>

<entity_types>
task      - Problem being solved (image classification, theorem proving, protein folding)
method    - Technique, algorithm, procedure (gradient descent, CRISPR, induction)
data      - Datasets, databases, benchmarks (ImageNet, MNIST, arXiv corpus)
artifact  - Pre-built: trained models, proof libraries (GPT-4, Mathlib, Cas9)
tool      - Software, instruments, platforms (PyTorch, Lean prover, microscope)
concept   - Abstract ideas, theories, frameworks (attention, category theory)
other     - Entities that don't fit above categories
</entity_types>

<relations>
uses     - Anything EXISTING that the paper uses (methods, datasets, tools, concepts, tasks)
proposes - Anything NEW/NOVEL that the paper creates or introduces

VALIDATION REQUIREMENTS:
- ALL papers MUST have at least 1 "uses" (papers always build on existing work)
- CONTRIBUTION papers MUST have at least 1 "proposes" (they must create something new)
</relations>

<output_json>
{
  "paper_type": "contribution" or "survey",
  "triples": [
    {
      "name": "Wikipedia Article Title",
      "relation": "uses|proposes",
      "entity_type": "task|method|data|artifact|tool|concept|other",
      "wikipedia_url": "https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/...",
      "relevance": "Why this matters (1 sentence)"
    }
  ]
}
</output_json>

<YOUR_TODO_LIST>
FIRST, add ALL of these to your todo list with "TodoWrite" tool:

CRITICAL: Todo content must be copied exactly as is written here, with NO CHANGES. These todos are intentionally detailed so that another LLM could read each one without any external context and understand exactly what it has to do.

1. Read ./triples_output.json. Classify paper as "contribution" or "survey". Edit triples_output.json to set paper_type field.

2. List ALL triples EXPLICITLY mentioned in title/abstract. For each, determine entity_type and relation.

3. For each triple: Use WebSearch tool with allowed_domains=["en.wikipedia.org"] to search "[entity name]" to find the correct Wikipedia article. IMPORTANT: Always include allowed_domains parameter to restrict to English Wikipedia.

4. Edit triples_output.json to add all triples. For each triple:
   - name: Use the Wikipedia article title (e.g., "Gradient descent" not "gradient descent algorithm")
   - relation: how paper relates to entity (uses or proposes)
   - entity_type: one of task, method, data, artifact, tool, concept, other
   - wikipedia_url: The Wikipedia URL from search results (must start with https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/)
   - relevance: 1 sentence explaining why it matters

5. Run validation: python validate_triple_json.py

6. If validation errors: Fix the errors (use WebSearch with allowed_domains=["en.wikipedia.org"] again if needed for incorrect URLs), edit triples_output.json, and rerun validation. MUST REPEAT until validation passes.

<CRITICAL_WEBSEARCH_INSTRUCTIONS>
When using WebSearch, you MUST use the allowed_domains parameter:
WebSearch(query="[your query]", allowed_domains=["en.wikipedia.org"])

This ensures only English Wikipedia results are returned. Do NOT search without allowed_domains.
</CRITICAL_WEBSEARCH_INSTRUCTIONS>
</YOUR_TODO_LIST>

Begin now.

## Paper Classification and Triple Extraction

Based on the paper abstract, this is a **"contribution"** paper because:
- It proposes a novel empirical study examining political communication networks on Twitter
- It introduces new insights about partisan structures and heterogeneous communication patterns
- It proposes a conjecture to explain the distinct topologies of different network types

### Triples Explicitly Mentioned in Title/Abstract:

1. **Twitter** - tool (social media platform used for analysis)
2. **Network clustering algorithms** - method (used to analyze retweets and mentions)
3. **Retweet** - concept (network structure analyzed)
4. **Mention network** - concept (user-to-user communication pattern)
5. **Political communication** - task (the problem being studied)
6. **U.S. congressional elections** - task/context (2010 midterm elections)
7. **Network analysis** - method (general analytical approach)
8. **Social media** - concept (the broader context)
9. **Partisan structure** - concept (finding about network organization)

Based on the search results, here's what I found about Twitter:

## Overview

X, formerly known as Twitter, is an American microblogging and social networking service.(no content)It is one of the world's largest social media platforms and one of the most-visited websites.

## Core Features

Users can share short text messages, images, and videos in short posts (which are informally known as tweets). Users could share concise text messages, images, and videos through "tweets" and engage with other users' content via likes or "retweets".

## History

Twitter was created by Jack Dorsey, Noah Glass, Biz Stone, and Evan Williams in March 2006 and was launched that July. The platform experienced significantgrowth over the years—by the start of 2019, Twitter had more than 330 million monthly active users.

## Recent Changes

Twitter was an American social networking service that was rebranded as X in 2023. This rebranding followed Twitter agreeing to a $44 billion buyout by Elon Musk, CEO of SpaceX and Tesla, on April 25, 2022.

Links: [{"title":"Political polarization - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Political_polarization"},{"title":"Political polarization in the United States - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Political_polarization_in_the_United_States"},{"title":"File:The IRA, Social Media and Political Polarization in the United States, 2012-2018.pdf - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/File:The_IRA,_Social_Media_and_Political_Polarization_in_the_United_States,_2012-2018.pdf"},{"title":"Political polarization in Turkey - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Political_polarization_in_Turkey"},{"title":"Negative partisanship - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Negative_partisanship"},{"title":"Partisan sorting - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Partisan_sorting"},{"title":"August 2023 Ohio Issue 1 - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/August_2023_Ohio_Issue_1"},{"title":"2025 North Macedonian local elections - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/2025_North_Macedonian_local_elections"},{"title":"Ground News - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Ground_News"},{"title":"Millennial politics - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Millennial_politics"}]

Here's an overview of political polarization based on the search results:

## Definition

Political polarization is the divergence of political attitudes away from the center, towards ideological extremes.(no content)Polarization is typically understood as "a prominent division or conflict that forms between major groups in a society or political system and that is marked by the clustering and radicalisation of views and beliefs at two distant and antagonistic poles."

## Types of Polarization

Scholars distinguish between ideological polarization (differences between the policy positions) and affective polarization (an emotional dislike and distrust of political out-groups).(no content)Political scientists typically distinguish between two levels of political polarization: elite polarization, which focuses on the polarization of the political elites like party organizers and elected officials, and mass polarization, which focuses on the polarization of the masses, most often the electorate or general public.

## Characteristics in Two-Party Systems

In a two-party system, a polarized legislature has little-to-no ideological overlap between members of the two parties, and almost all conflict over legislation and policies is split across a broad ideological divide. This leads to a conflation of political parties and ideologies and the collapse of an ideological center.

## Trends in the United States

Polarization has increased since the 1970s, with rapid increases in polarization during the 2000s onwards. According to the Pew Research Center, members of both parties who have unfavorable opinions of the opposing party have doubled since 1994, while those who have very unfavorable opinions of the opposing party are at record highs as of 2022.

Web search results for query: "Graph partitioning clustering"

Links: [{"title":"Graph partition - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Graph_partition"},{"title":"Spectral clustering - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Spectral_clustering"},{"title":"HCS clustering algorithm - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/HCS_clustering_algorithm"},{"title":"Louvain method - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Louvain_method"},{"title":"Cluster analysis - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Cluster_analysis"},{"title":"METIS - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/METIS"},{"title":"Clustering coefficient - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Clustering_coefficient"},{"title":"Hierarchical clustering - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Hierarchical_clustering"},{"title":"List of partition topics - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Partition_(mathematics)"},{"title":"Hierarchical clustering of networks - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Hierarchical_clustering_of_networks"}]

## Graph Partitioning Clustering - Search Results

Here's an overview of graph partitioning and clustering based on the search results:

### Definition and Basics

A graph partition is the reduction of a graph to a smaller graph by partitioning its set of nodes into mutually exclusive groups.(no content)Since graph partitioning is a hard problem, practical solutions are based on heuristics.

### Approaches and Methods

There are two broad categories of methods, local and global. Well-known local methods are the Kernighan–Lin algorithm, and Fiduccia-Mattheyses algorithms.(no content)Global approaches rely on properties of the entire graph and do not rely on an arbitrary initial partition. The most common example is spectral partitioning, where a partition is derived from approximate eigenvectors of the adjacency matrix, or spectral clustering that groups graph vertices using the eigendecomposition of the graph Laplacian matrix.

### Multi-level Approach

A multi-level graph partitioning algorithm works by applying one or more stages. Each stage reduces the size of the graph by collapsing vertices and edges, partitions the smaller graph, then maps back and refines this partition of the original graph.(no content)One widely used example of such an approach is METIS, a graph partitioner, and hMETIS, the corresponding partitioner for hypergraphs.

### Community Detection

Related to graph partitioning is community detection. The Louvain method for community detection is a greedy optimization method intended to extract non-overlapping communities from large networks.(no content)Modularity is a scale value between −1 (non-modular clustering) and 1 (fully modular clustering) that measures the relative density of edges inside communities with respect to edges outside communities.

Web search results for query: "Network clustering algorithm"

Links: [{"title":"Hierarchical clustering of networks - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Hierarchical_clustering_of_networks"},{"title":"Cluster analysis - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Cluster_analysis"},{"title":"Clustering coefficient - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Clustering_coefficient"},{"title":"HCS clustering algorithm - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/HCS_clustering_algorithm"},{"title":"KHOPCA clustering algorithm - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/KHOPCA_clustering_algorithm"},{"title":"Leiden algorithm - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Leiden_algorithm"},{"title":"Automatic clustering algorithms - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Automatic_clustering_algorithms"},{"title":"Ward's method - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Ward's_method"},{"title":"Correlation clustering - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Correlation_clustering"},{"title":"Spectral clustering - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Spectral_clustering"}]

Here's an overview of network clustering algorithms based on the search results:

## Definition and Purpose

Cluster analysis refers to a family of algorithms and tasks rather than one specific algorithm, with various algorithms that differ significantly in their understanding of what constitutes a cluster and how to efficiently find them.

## Key Network Clustering Algorithms

### Hierarchical Clustering
One divisive technique is the Girvan–Newman algorithm.(no content)As links are added, connected subsets begin to form, representing the network's community structures.

### HCS Algorithm
The Highly Connected Subgraphs (HCS) clustering algorithm is an algorithm based on graph connectivity for cluster analysis that works by representing the similarity data in a similarity graph, and then finding all the highly connected subgraphs.(no content)It does not make any prior assumptions on the number of the clusters.

### Leiden Algorithm
The Leiden algorithm is a community detection algorithm developed by Traag et al at Leiden University, developed as a modification of the Louvain method.(no content)Like the Louvain method, the Leiden algorithm attempts to optimize modularity in extracting communities from networks; however, it addresses key issues present in the Louvain method, namely poorly connected communities and the resolution limit of modularity.

### Correlation Clustering
Correlation clustering provides a method for clustering a set of objects into the optimum number of clusters without specifying that number in advance, operating in a scenario where the relationships between the objects are known instead of the actual representations of the objects.

### Spectral Clustering
Spectral clustering techniques make use of the spectrum (eigenvalues) of the similarity matrix of the data to perform dimensionality reduction before clustering in fewer dimensions, with the similarity matrix consisting of a quantitative assessment of the relative similarity of each pair of points in the dataset.

Cluster analysis refers to a family of algorithms and tasks rather than one specific algorithm, with various algorithms that differ significantly in their understanding of what constitutes a cluster and how to efficiently find them.

## Key Network Clustering Algorithms

### Hierarchical Clustering
One divisive technique is the Girvan–Newman algorithm.(no content)As links are added, connected subsets begin to form, representing the network's community structures.

### HCS Algorithm
The Highly Connected Subgraphs (HCS) clustering algorithm is an algorithm based on graph connectivity for cluster analysis that works by representing the similarity data in a similarity graph, and then finding all the highly connected subgraphs.(no content)It does not make any prior assumptions on the number of the clusters.

### Leiden Algorithm
The Leiden algorithm is a community detection algorithm developed by Traag et al at Leiden University, developed as a modification of the Louvain method.(no content)Like the Louvain method, the Leiden algorithm attempts to optimize modularity in extracting communities from networks; however, it addresses key issues present in the Louvain method, namely poorly connected communities and the resolution limit of modularity.

### Correlation Clustering
Correlation clustering provides a method for clustering a set of objects into the optimum number of clusters without specifying that number in advance, operating in a scenario where the relationships between the objects are known instead of the actual representations of the objects.

### Spectral Clustering
Spectral clustering techniques make use of the spectrum (eigenvalues) of the similarity matrix of the data to perform dimensionality reduction before clustering in fewer dimensions, with the similarity matrix consisting of a quantitative assessment of the relative similarity of each pair of points in the dataset.

I've performed the web search for "Community detection network clustering." Here's a summary of the key findings:

## Overview

Community structure in networks refers to the occurrence of groups of nodes in a network that are more densely connected internally than with the rest of the network.(no content)Being able to identify these sub-structures within a network can provide insight into how network function and topology affect each other.

## Major Algorithms

**Modularity Maximization:**
The modularity maximization method detects communities by searching for divisions with high modularity, with the Louvain method being a popular approach that iteratively optimizes local communities until global modularity can no longer be improved.

**Leiden Algorithm:**
The Leiden algorithm attempts to optimize modularity in extracting communities from networks and addresses key issues in the Louvain method by employing an intermediate refinement phase in which communities may be split to guarantee that all communities are well-connected.

**Girvan-Newman Algorithm:**
The Girvan–Newman algorithm is a hierarchical method used to detect communities in complex systems that detects communities by progressively removing edges from the original network, with the connected components of the remaining network being the communities.

**Hierarchical Clustering:**
Hierarchical clustering is one method for finding community structures in a network that arranges the network into a hierarchy of groups according to a specified weight function and represents the data in a tree structure known as a dendrogram.

**Spectral Clustering:**
Spectral clustering has been successfully applied on large graphs by first identifying their community structure, and then clustering communities.

I've performed a web search for "Online social networks" and found comprehensive information. Here's an overview based on the results:

## Definition

A social networking service or social networking site (SNS) is a type of online social media platform which people use to build social networks or social relationships with other people who share similar personal or career content, interests, activities, backgrounds or real-life connections.

## Key Features

Social networking services vary in format and the number of features, and can incorporate a range of new information and communication tools, operating on desktops and laptops, as well as on mobile devices such as tablet computers and smartphones.(no content)Social networking sites allow users to share ideas, digital photos and videos, posts, and to inform others about online or real-world activities and events with people within their social network.

## Evolution

Early social networking on the World Wide Web began in the form of generalized online communities such as Theglobe.com (1995), GeoCities (1994) and Tripod.com (1995), which focused on bringing people together to interact with each other through chat rooms and encouraged users to share personal information via personal web pages.(no content)Notable social networking sites began to flourish with the emergence of SixDegrees in 1997, Open Diary in 1998, and subsequent platforms like Friendster and Nexopia in 2003, with MySpace and LinkedIn also launched in 2003.

## Current Usage

As of 2023, as many as 4.76 billion people used social media, some 59% of the global population.

## Web Search Results for "Social Network Analysis"

I've found comprehensive information about social network analysis. Here are the key findings:

### Definition
Social network analysis (SNA) is the process of investigating social structures through the use of networks and graph theory, characterizing networked structures in terms of nodes (individual actors, people, or things within the network) and the ties, edges, or links (relationships or interactions) that connect them.

### Applications
Examples of social structures commonly visualized through social network analysis include social media networks, meme proliferation, information circulation, friendship and acquaintance networks, business networks, knowledge networks, difficult working relationships, collaboration graphs, kinship, disease transmission, and sexual relationships.

### Historical Development
Social network analysis has its theoretical roots in the work of early sociologists such as Georg Simmel and Émile Durkheim, who wrote about the importance of studying patterns of relationships that connect social actors, with social scientists using the concept of "social networks" since early in the 20th century to connote complex sets of relationships.

### Visualization
These networks are often visualized through sociograms in which nodes are represented as points and ties are represented as lines, which provide a means of qualitatively assessing networks by varying the visual representation of their nodes and edges to reflect attributes of interest.

### Key Metrics
Metrics encountered in social network analysis include those measuring the size, the nature of connections between members being analyzed, distribution, and segmentation - including subsets such as multiplexity, propinquity, density, centrality, and cohesion.

## Web Search Results for "Social Network Analysis"

I've found comprehensive information about social network analysis. Here are the key findings:

### Definition
Social network analysis (SNA) is the process of investigating social structures through the use of networks and graph theory, characterizing networked structures in terms of nodes (individual actors, people, or things within the network) and the ties, edges, or links (relationships or interactions) that connect them.

### Applications
Examples of social structures commonly visualized through social network analysis include social media networks, meme proliferation, information circulation, friendship and acquaintance networks, business networks, knowledge networks, difficult working relationships, collaboration graphs, kinship, disease transmission, and sexual relationships.

### Historical Development
Social network analysis has its theoretical roots in the work of early sociologists such as Georg Simmel and Émile Durkheim, who wrote about the importance of studying patterns of relationships that connect social actors, with social scientists using the concept of "social networks" since early in the 20th century to connote complex sets of relationships.

### Visualization
These networks are often visualized through sociograms in which nodes are represented as points and ties are represented as lines, which provide a means of qualitatively assessing networks by varying the visual representation of their nodes and edges to reflect attributes of interest.

### Key Metrics
Metrics encountered in social network analysis include those measuring the size, the nature of connections between members being analyzed, distribution, and segmentation - including subsets such as multiplexity, propinquity, density, centrality, and cohesion.


REMINDER: You MUST include the sources above in your response to the user using markdown hyperlinks.

todos.content: List ALL triples EXPLICITLY mentioned in title/abstract. For each, determine entity_type and relation.
todos.activeForm: Listing all triples from title and abstract

todos.content: For each triple: Use WebSearch tool with allowed_domains=["en.wikipedia.org"] to search "[entity name]" to find the correct Wikipedia article. IMPORTANT: Always include allowed_domains parameter to restrict to English Wikipedia.
todos.activeForm: Searching for Wikipedia articles for each triple

todos.content: Edit triples_output.json to add all triples. For each triple: name: Use the Wikipedia article title (e.g., "Gradient descent" not "gradient descent algorithm"), relation: how paper relates to entity (uses or proposes), entity_type: one of task, method, data, artifact, tool, concept, other, wikipedia_url: The Wikipedia URL from search results (must start with https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/), relevance: 1 sentence explaining why it matters
todos.activeForm: Editing triples_output.json with all triple data

todos.content: Run validation: python validate_triple_json.py
todos.activeForm: Running validation script

todos.content: If validation errors: Fix the errors (use WebSearch with allowed_domains=["en.wikipedia.org"] again if needed for incorrect URLs), edit triples_output.json, and rerun validation. MUST REPEAT until validation passes.
todos.activeForm: Fixing validation errors if needed

purpose: Extract transferable techniques and methodologies from research papers

message_text:
Perfect! All tasks have been completed successfully. Here's a summary of what was accomplished:

## Analysis Complete ✅

### Paper Classification
The paper "Political Polarization on Twitter" has been classified as a **contribution** because it:
- Proposes a novel empirical study of political communication networks
- Introduces new insights about partisan segregation in retweets vs. mentions
- Provides new statistical evidence about network topologies

### Extracted Triples (5 entities)

1. **Twitter** (tool) - Uses: The primary social media platform for data collection
2. **Community structure** (method) - Uses: Network clustering algorithms for detecting partisan organization
3. **Social network analysis** (method) - Uses: Foundational methodology for analyzing network topology
4. **Political polarization** (task) - Proposes: New empirical evidence demonstrating segregated partisan structures
5. **Graph partition** (method) - Uses: Underlying concepts for network clustering algorithms

All triples have been validated and the JSON output meets all requirements:
- ✅ Paper type is correctly set
- ✅ All entities have valid Wikipedia URLs
- ✅ Each triple includes proper entity types (tool, method, task)
- ✅ Relations correctly specify uses vs. proposes
- ✅ At least 1 "uses" relation exists (validation requirement)
- ✅ At least 1 "proposes" relation exists (contribution paper requirement)

The validation script confirms everything is properly formatted and all checks passed.
